abstract.p: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Baldoria, new Rao's offspring opened by Frank Pellegrino Jr on theater district; photo (S)

block.p: Baldoria has been open less than a month, but it already feels as if it has been around for 50 years. It's the kind of Italian restaurant that New York could get a patent on, with tall booths in maroon leather, dark wood floors and the music of Frank and Dino emanating from a jukebox. You can spot the place fairly easily. It's the only restaurant in the theater district with a doorman in bow tie and sunglasses.
Baldoria is the offspring of Rao's, the legendary southern Italian restaurant in East Harlem where tables are booked year-round by a small group of regulars.

The unvarying answer to requests for a reservation earned the restaurant's owner, Frank Pellegrino, the nickname Frankie No.
His son, Frank Jr., is making it a lot easier on diners at Baldoria. The restaurant has two dining rooms, upstairs and downstairs, and an orthodox reservation policy.

The menu is traditional and pan-Italian, with appetizers like roasted peppers, vitello tonnato, sauteed clams and a chilled seafood salad of shrimp, squid and lobster. A seasonal surprise was a very fresh salad of fava beans and wild French asparagus served with a scoop of ricotta cheese.

Risotto with sliced white asparagus, a special, is outstanding. Orecchiette with sausage, broccoli rape and pepperoncini led a list of pastas that included gnocchi alla bolognese, penne in a spicy arrabbiata sauce, and ribbonlike trenette with prosciutto, peas and onions in a light cream sauce.

Main courses tend to be old friends like veal piccata, osso buco, veal pizzaiola and bistecca alla fiorentina, although a nicely seared grouper, served very simply with sherry and fresh herbs, broke the spell momentarily.

The wine list at present is meager. Baldoria throws some effort into the desserts, often a big letdown at Italian restaurants. Almond panna cotta, thickly luxurious, comes with an intensely flavored hazelnut ice cream, and the bitter chocolate tart, almost black, rests in a delicate, paper-thin pastry crust that, heaven forbid, seems French.
At the end of the meal, Frank Jr. dropped by the table and asked, ''Is there anything we could have done to make your meal a more positive experience?''
Only one thing came to mind. Drop Sade from the jukebox, and rustle up a recording of ''Relaxez-Vous'' by Dino.
Baldoria, 249 West 49th Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-0460. Dinner entrees, $15.50 to $32.
